item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:37, topic:58208”]Amarok is the best media player I have ever used, Kopete is the best instant messenger I have ever used, and tonight I will search and find you a better html developing program than dreamweaver (which personally I never liked better than notepad)
…
I like OpenOffice much more than Microsoft Office, I even use it on windows computers :)[/quote]

I actually use Dreamweaver for its code view. It’s upload-on-save feature and ftp access are clinchers, not to mention its built-in validator and browser support check.

And OpenOffice really has nothing on Office 07.

If you can make something like this easily with OpenOffice, maybe I’ll take a look.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @DeadBird DeadBird
item.description:
@DeadBird wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:37, topic:58208”][quote author=xxlegitxx link=topic=83412.msg906826#msg906826 date=1171635467]
I must agree with you… even programs like Kopete, Amarok, or a Dreamweaver-for-Linux cannot compare with Windows programs. Nothing by linux could possibly rival iTunes or Dreamweaver.
[/quote]

Amarok is the best media player I have ever used, Kopete is the best instant messenger I have ever used, and tonight I will search and find you a better html developing program than dreamweaver (which personally I never liked better than notepad)

Windows, cause I use too many Windows applications. OpenOffice sucks and I use Office alot is my main problem.
If you tell me to emulate, I’ll hit you with a stick.

I like OpenOffice much more than Microsoft Office, I even use it on windows computers :)[/quote]
Well, you’re open source obsessed :. Its not a surprise.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Playing Wow on linux is a piece of piss, if you already happen to have it installed.

“wine WoW.exe”.

The only problems I had were with the installer, they didn’t like it much.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:28, topic:58208”][quote author=Tree link=topic=83412.msg903551#msg903551 date=1171561123]
I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.
[/quote]

I can’t think of a task that is easier to do on windows than linux… not a single one.

I don’t use linux to be rebellious, I use it because it’s a decent OS, and windows sucks. Windows was maybe built for ease of use, but I prefer productivity and stability, and as I said, there’s nothing that’s easier to do on Windows than Linux now anyway really.[/quote]What about playing WoW?

Oh snap.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:28, topic:58208”]I can’t think of a task that is easier to do on windows than linux… not a single one.

I don’t use linux to be rebellious, I use it because it’s a decent OS, and windows sucks. Windows was maybe built for ease of use, but I prefer productivity and stability, and as I said, there’s nothing that’s easier to do on Windows than Linux now anyway really.[/quote]

Web design. Don’t think you can find a program that can best Dreamweaver.

And I really don’t think Linux is much stabler. On Ubuntu Edgy, I’ve had the system just freeze, and not open any windows or respond for quite a while. Maybe because I’m on edgy, but I don’t see this as more productive or stable.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:23, topic:58208”]I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.[/quote]

I must agree with you… even programs like Kopete, Amarok, or a Dreamweaver-for-Linux cannot compare with Windows programs. Nothing by linux could possibly rival iTunes or Dreamweaver.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:23, topic:58208”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=83412.msg900569#msg900569 date=1171500445]

I can’t get Wine to work though, so I can’t use dreamweaver, itunes, or trillian.

You’re still stuck on windows applications, there are better programs than dreamweaver I am sure.

Use amarok instead of itunes.

Use Kopete instead of trillian.

Alternatives people, free, open source alternatives, that is why I like linux (not to mention Wine does work, if you have to)

Personally I use Kubuntu 6.10, anything based on debian rules.
[/quote]

I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.[/quote]

Quite a few things are much easier in linux than windows, updating, customizing boot options and much much more. Like Mopman said I can’t think of a single thing that is easier to do on windows than on linux.

I simply mentioned that one could use Wine to run a windows program if they need, but the point I was making is that there is an open source alternative that is 99% of the time better than the proprietary software.

Open source provides a lot of great things besides just knowledge, it makes me feel secure when I know that thousands of programmers from all around the world worked on and approved of the programs I am using. That is much better than 10 guys at microsoft programming something god-knows-how.

Javacisnotrecognized:

There’s no equivelant to DirectX on Linux.

No, but there is something superior: OpenGL

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:23, topic:58208”]I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.[/quote]

I can’t think of a task that is easier to do on windows than linux… not a single one.

I don’t use linux to be rebellious, I use it because it’s a decent OS, and windows sucks. Windows was maybe built for ease of use, but I prefer productivity and stability, and as I said, there’s nothing that’s easier to do on Windows than Linux now anyway really.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:24, topic:58208”][quote author=Tree link=topic=83412.msg903551#msg903551 date=1171561123]

I can’t get Wine to work though, so I can’t use dreamweaver, itunes, or trillian.

You’re still stuck on windows applications, there are better programs than dreamweaver I am sure.

Use amarok instead of itunes.

Use Kopete instead of trillian.

Alternatives people, free, open source alternatives, that is why I like linux (not to mention Wine does work, if you have to)

Personally I use Kubuntu 6.10, anything based on debian rules.

I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.
[/quote]

Linux isn’t a ‘non computer persons’ computer. If you have someone who knows nothing about a computer except that the power button turns it on, they won’t understand linux. Windows is the opposite. It’s designed with a UI where everything is layed out for you, and a menu where you can choose to do all the most common tasks in a way designed for speed. (In a sense that the software uses Windows specific API and hardware/kernel features). From a programming aspect, Windows is more UI oriented as well: There’s no equivelant to DirectX on Linux.[/quote]

As i stated earlier.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:23, topic:58208”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=83412.msg900569#msg900569 date=1171500445]

I can’t get Wine to work though, so I can’t use dreamweaver, itunes, or trillian.

You’re still stuck on windows applications, there are better programs than dreamweaver I am sure.

Use amarok instead of itunes.

Use Kopete instead of trillian.

Alternatives people, free, open source alternatives, that is why I like linux (not to mention Wine does work, if you have to)

Personally I use Kubuntu 6.10, anything based on debian rules.
[/quote]

I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.[/quote]

Linux isn’t a ‘non computer persons’ computer. If you have someone who knows nothing about a computer except that the power button turns it on, they won’t understand linux. Windows is the opposite. It’s designed with a UI where everything is layed out for you, and a menu where you can choose to do all the most common tasks in a way designed for speed. (In a sense that the software uses Windows specific API and hardware/kernel features). From a programming aspect, Windows is more UI oriented as well: There’s no equivelant to DirectX on Linux.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows, Apple, Linux
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:19, topic:58208”][quote author=xxlegitxx link=topic=83412.msg899554#msg899554 date=1171482390]
I can’t get Wine to work though, so I can’t use dreamweaver, itunes, or trillian.
[/quote]

You’re still stuck on windows applications, there are better programs than dreamweaver I am sure.

Use amarok instead of itunes.

Use Kopete instead of trillian.

Alternatives people, free, open source alternatives, that is why I like linux (not to mention Wine does work, if you have to)

Personally I use Kubuntu 6.10, anything based on debian rules.[/quote]

I can safely say people only like linux due to the fact it’s not what the majority of computer users are using. Sure Linux has it’s uses as a server but it simply doesn’t cut it when it comes to the amount of reliable software made for it and others extensive customer support.

You give the excuse of wine (the windows emulator), but please explain to me why someone should go to that trouble when you can run it in two clicks on windows? It’s like buying a TV, then turning it into a pc when you could just have used your originial pc in the first place.

Open source means nothing to the general populous, and Microsoft have done a great job turning something considerably hard to a new computer user, easy in a safe and rewarding enviroment (GUI wise).

Linux wouldn’t even make second on my list as greatest OS, it would make third and Mac and Windows fighting it up at first and second place. You say Linux is all great but it isn’t, it makes easy tasks available on Windows or Mac a great deal mundane and useless. Rebellion is the keyword, and i wouldn’t say its the way to go.
